facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Jury Reference No. 159 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Jury Reference No. 159 of 1959. S. Pathak, S. G. Patwardhan, Rajini Patel, Porus A. Metha, J. B. Dadachaji, Ravinder Narain and O. C. Mathur, for the appellant.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J. on November 24, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by special leave arises out of the judgment of the Bombay High Court sentencing Nanavati, the appellant, to life imprisonment for the murder of Prem Bhagwandas Ahuja, a businessman of Bombay.

facts.text: Bombay High Court sentenced Nanavati to life imprisonment for the murder of Prem Bhagwandas Ahuja.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of the judgment of the Bombay High Court sentencing Nanavati, the appellant, to life imprisonment for the murder of Prem Bhagwandas Ahuja, a businessman of Bombay. This appeal presents the commonplace problem of an alleged murder by an enraged husband of a paramour of his wife but it aroused considerable interest in the public mind by reason of the publicity it received and the important constitutional point it had given rise to at the time of its admission.

facts.text: Nanavati was charged under s. 302 as well as under s. 304, Part I, of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged under s. 302 as well as under s. 304, Part I, of the Indian Penal Code and was tried by the Sessions Judge, Greater Bombay, with the aid of special jury. The jury brought in a verdict of not guilty by 8:1 under both the sections but the Sessions Judge did not agree with the verdict of the jury, as in his view the majority verdict of the jury was such that no reasonable body of men could, having regard to the evidence, bring in such a verdict.

facts.text: Jury brought in a verdict of not guilty by 8:1 under both sections.

anchor.surface_text: The jury brought in a verdict of not guilty by 8:1 under both the sections but the Sessions Judge did not agree with the verdict of the jury, as in his view the majority verdict of the jury was such that no reasonable body of men could, having regard to the evidence, bring in such a verdict.

facts.text: Sessions Judge disagreed with jury verdict and submitted case under s. 307 CrPC to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge did not agree with the verdict of the jury, as in his view the majority verdict of the jury was such that no reasonable body of men could, having regard to the evidence, bring in such a verdict. The learned Sessions Judge submitted the case under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to the Bombay High Court after recording the grounds for his opinion.

facts.text: Shelat and Naik JJ of Bombay High Court held accused guilty under s. 302 IPC and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: The said reference was heard by a division bench of the said High Court consisting of Shelat and Naik, JJ. The two learned Judges gave separate judgments, but agreed in holding that the accused was guilty of the offence of murder under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Nanavati was second in command of INS Mysore at time of murder.

anchor.surface_text: This accused, at the time of the alleged murder, was second in command of the Indian Naval Ship Mysore. He married Sylvia in 1949 in the registry office at Portsmouth, England.

facts.text: Nanavati married Sylvia in 1949 in Portsmouth, England. They have three children.

anchor.surface_text: He married Sylvia in 1949 in the registry office at Portsmouth, England. They have three children by the marriage, a boy aged 9 1/2 years a girl aged 5 1/2 years and another boy aged 3 years.

facts.text: Ahuja was unmarried businessman about 34 years old at death, residing in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In the same city the deceased Ahuja was doing business in automobiles and was residing, along with his sister, in a building called Shreyas till 1957 and thereafter in another building called Jivan Jyot in Setalvad Road.

facts.text: Agniks introduced Ahuja and sister to Nanavatis in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1956, Agniks, who were common friends of Nanavatis and Ahujas, introduced Ahuja and his sister to Nanavatis.

facts.text: Friendship developed between Ahuja and Sylvia culminating in illicit intimacy.

anchor.surface_text: Gradually, friendship developed between Ahuja and Sylvia, which culminated in illicit intimacy between them.

facts.text: On April 27, 1959, Sylvia confessed to Nanavati her illicit intimacy with Ahuja.

anchor.surface_text: On April 27, 1959, Sylvia confessed to Nanavati of her illicit intimacy with Ahuja.

facts.text: Enraged, Nanavati took semi-automatic revolver and six cartridges from ship stores on false pretext, loaded it, went to Ahuja's flat, entered bedroom and shot him dead.

anchor.surface_text: Enraged at the conduct of Ahuja, Nanavati went to his ship, took from the stores of the ship a semi- automatic revolver and six cartridges on a false pretext, loaded the same, went to the flat of Ahuja entered his bed-room and shot him dead.

facts.text: Accused surrendered himself to the police after shooting.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the accused surrendered himself to the police. He was put under arrest and in due course he was committed to the Sessions for facing a charge under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Defence: Accused away with ship April 6 to 18, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The defence version, as disclosed in the Statement made by the accused before the Sessions Court under s. 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and his deposition in the said Court, may be briefly stated The accused was away with his ship from April 6, 1959, to April 18, 1959.

facts.text: Wife Sylvia confessed unfaithfulness on April 27, 1959, during lunch.

anchor.surface_text: At noon on April 27, 1959, when they were sitting in the sitting-room for the lunch to be served, the accused put his arm round his wife affectionately, when she seemed to go tense and unresponsive.

facts.text: Accused went to Ahuja's flat, confronted him about marrying Sylvia, struggle ensued, shots fired accidentally.

anchor.surface_text: The accused saw the deceased inside the bed-room, called him a filthy swine and asked him whether he would marry Sylvia and look after the children. The deceased retorted, Am I to marry every woman I sleep with ? The accused became enraged, put the envelope containing the revolver on a cabinet nearby, and threatened to thrash the deceased. The deceased made a sudden move to grasp at the envelope, when the accused whipped out his revolver and told him to get back. A struggle ensued between the two and during that struggle two shots went off accidentally and hit Ahuja resulting in his death.

facts.text: Sessions Judge charged jury but had misdirections according to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Shelat, J., having held that there were misdirections to the jury, reviewed the entire evidence and came to the conclusion that the accused was clearly guilty of the offence of murder,

facts.text: High Court reviewed entire evidence and found accused guilty of murder.

anchor.surface_text: reviewed the entire evidence and came to the conclusion that the accused was clearly guilty of the offence of murder, alternatively, he expressed the view that the verdict of the jury was perverse, unreasonable and, in any event, contrary to the weight of evidence.

facts.text: No case made out to reduce offence from murder to culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Judges agreed that no case had been made out to reduce the offence from murder to culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

facts.text: Nanavati drove wife and children to cinema before going to ship for revolver.

anchor.surface_text: Sylvia pleaded with him not go to Ahujas house, as he might shoot him. Thereafter, he drove his wife, two of his children and a neighbours child in his car to a cinema, dropped them there and promised to come and pick them up at 6 P.M. when the show ended.

facts.text: Obtained revolver from ship by pretext of driving alone to Ahmednagar.

anchor.surface_text: He then drove his car to his ship, as he wanted to get medicine for his sick dog, he represented to the authorities in the ship, that he wanted to draw a revolver and six rounds from the stores of the ship as he was going to drive alone to Ahmednagar by night, though the real purpose was to shoot himself.

facts.text: Ahuja retorted 'Am I to marry every woman I sleep with?' during confrontation.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased retorted, Am I to marry every woman I sleep with ? The accused became enraged, put the envelope containing the revolver on a cabinet nearby, and threatened to thrash the deceased.

facts.text: Two shots went off during struggle resulting in Ahuja's death.

anchor.surface_text: A struggle ensued between the two and during that struggle two shots went off accidentally and hit Ahuja resulting in his death.

issues.text: Under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the High Court should decide whether a reference made by a Sessions Judge was competent only on a perusal of the order of reference made to it and it had no jurisdiction to consider the evidence and come to a conclusion whether the reference was competent or not.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the High Court should decide whether a reference made by a Sessions Judge was competent only on a perusal of the order of reference made to it and it had no jurisdiction to consider the evidence and come to a conclusion whether the reference was competent or not.

issues.text: Under s. 307(3) of the said Code, the High Court had no power to set aside the verdict of a jury on the ground that there were misdirections in the charge made by the Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 307(3) of the said Code, the High Court had no power to set aside the verdict of a jury on the ground that there were misdirections in the charge made by the Sessions Judge.

issues.text: The verdict of the jury was not perverse and it was such that a reasonable body of persons could arrive at it on the evidence placed before them. In any view, the accused shot at the deceased under grave and sudden provocation, and therefore even if he had committed an offence, it would not be murder but only culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

holdings.text: The competency of a reference made by a Sessions Judge under s.307 CrPC depends upon two conditions: (i) disagreement with jury verdict, (ii) clear opinion that verdict is one no reasonable body of men could reach on evidence, recording grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The foregoing discussion may be summarized in the form of the following propositions  1  The competency of a reference made by a Sessions Judge depends upon the existence of two conditions, namely,  i  that he disagrees with the verdict of the jurors,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory construction of s.307(1) CrPC; historical evolution; Privy Council in Ramanugrah Singh distinguished; conditions from text and JC interpretation.

holdings.text: If reference order shows non-compliance with conditions or no grounds recorded, High Court rejects as incompetent; also if s.307(2) contravened.

anchor.surface_text: and  ii  that he is clearly of the opinion that the verdict is one which no reasonable body of men could have reached on the evidence, after reaching that opinion,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct from s.307 text; ex facie determination from submitted case.

holdings.text: Once conditions satisfied in reference, s.307(3) mandates High Court consider entire evidence, give due weight to Sessions Judge and jury opinions, then acquit or convict.

anchor.surface_text: in the case submitted by him he shall record the grounds of his opinion.  2  If the case submitted shows that the conditions have not been complied with

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory mandate; distinguishes from appeal jurisdiction under ss.418,423; wider powers when Judge disagrees.

holdings.text: Under s.307(3), High Court may: (i) if misdirections vitiate verdict, disregard jury verdict after reviewing evidence; (ii) if no misdirections but verdict perverse/unreasonable, interfere.

anchor.surface_text: or that the reasons for the opinion are not recorded, the High Court may reject the reference as incompetent the High Court can also reject it if the Sessions Judge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of s.307(3) with appeal limits; purpose to prevent injustice from perverse verdicts; weight depends on vitiation/misdir.

holdings.text: High Court on reference under s.307 exercises procedural powers of appellate court appropriate to occasion (notice, records, remand, retrial).

anchor.surface_text: has contravened sub-s.  2  of s. 307.  3  If the case submitted shows that the Sessions Judge has disagreed with the verdict of the jury

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.307(3) first part: powers as on appeal, subject to second part; limited to procedural.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge's charge had grave omissions re s.105 Evidence Act presumption and s.80 IPC ingredients/burden, mixing offence and exception, vitiating verdict.

anchor.surface_text: The first omission is that throughout the entire charge there is no reference to s. 105 of the Evidence Act or to the statutory presumption laid down in that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty to explain law/burdens; lay jury needs direction; failure to distinguish burdens, explain terms.

holdings.text: s.105 Evidence Act presumes absence of general exception circumstances against accused; burden on accused to rebut (disprove), but prosecution proves offence ingredients always.

anchor.surface_text: Section 105 When a person is accused of any offence, the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the General Exceptions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: presume absence till disproved (s.3,4); no conflict with prosecution burden; three situations distinguished; Woolmington reconciled.

holdings.text: Charge misdirected by treating case as purely circumstantial (stringent rules) despite direct extra-judicial confession evidence, vitiating verdict.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the prosecution relies on what is called circumstantial evidence that is to say there is no witness who can say that he saw the accused actually shooting

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeated emphasis on circumstantial standard post-confession mention; jury may have misapplied higher burden.

holdings.text: Omission to refer/explain Sylvia's letters in charge (crucial to credibility/state of mind) amounts to misdirection vitiating verdict.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be gainsaid that these letters were important documents disclosing the state of mind of Mrs. Nanavati and the deceased to a certain extent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letters key to testing evidence; jury needs judicial guidance on importance; not cured by counsel reading.

holdings.text: Bombay High Court correctly exercised s.307 powers: found misdirections vitiating verdict, reviewed evidence, held accused guilty of murder u/s 302 IPC, no reduction to culpable homicide.

anchor.surface_text: Shelat, J., having held that there were misdirections to the jury, reviewed the entire evidence and came to the conclusion that the accused was clearly guilty of the offence of murder,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld as per wide s.307 powers; multiple misdirs confirmed; no grave sudden provocation; evidence supports murder.

anchor.surface_text: But the Judicial Committee, in Ramanugrah Singh v. King Emperor 1 , construed the words necessary for the ends of justice and laid down that the words mean that the Judge shall be of the opinion that the verdict of the jury is one which no reasonable body of men could have reached on the evidence.

precedents.cited_proposition: construed 'necessary for the ends of justice' to mean verdict no reasonable body could reach
precedents.cited_holding: the verdict was one which no reasonable body of men could have, reached on the evidence

anchor.surface_text: But it is said that it is borne out of the decision of the Judicial Committee in Ramanugrah Singhs case 1 . In that case the Judicial Committee relied upon the words ends of justice end held that the verdict was one which no reasonable body of men could have, reached on the evidence and further laid down that the requirements of the ends of justice must be the determining factor both for the Sessions Judge in making the reference and for the High Court in disposing of it.

precedents.cited_proposition: requirements of ends of justice determine reference and disposal

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee observed In general, if the evidence is such that it can properly support a verdict either of guilty or not guilty, according to the view taken of it by the trial court, and if the jury take one view of the evidence and the judge thinks that they should have taken the other, the view of the jury. must prevail, since they are the judges of fact.

precedents.cited_proposition: if evidence supports either verdict, jury view prevails unless unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: In Ramanugrah Singhs case  1 , which have been referred to earlier, the Judicial Committee described the wide amplitude of the power of the High Court in the following terms The Court must consider the whole case and give due weight to the opinions of the Sessions Judge and jury, and than acquit or convict the accused.

precedents.cited_proposition: wide power under s.307 to consider whole case

precedents.citation: Akhlakali Hayatalli v. The State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Akhlakali Hayatalli v. The State of Bombay accepted the view of the Judicial Committee on the construction of s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and applied it to the facts of that case.

precedents.case_name: Akhlakali Hayatalli v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: accepted JC view on s.307 construction

precedents.citation: Ratan Rai v. State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: So too the decision of this court in Ratan Rai v. State of Bihar assumes that such an interference is permissible if the verdict of the jury was vitiated by misdirections.

precedents.case_name: Ratan Rai v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court can interfere if misdirections vitiate verdict

precedents.citation: Sashi Mohan Debnath The State of West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: This Court again in Sashi Mohan Debnath The State of West Bengal, held that where the Sessions Judge disagreed with the verdict of the jury and was of the opinion that the case should be submitted to the High Court, he should submit the whole case and not a part of it.

precedents.case_name: Sashi Mohan Debnath v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Sessions Judge must submit whole case under s.307(2)

anchor.surface_text: The decision of a division bench of the Patna High Court in Emperor v. Ramadhar Kurmi may usefully be referred to as it throws some light on the question whether the High Court can interfere with the verdict of the jury when it is vitiated by serious misdirections and non-directions.

precedents.cited_proposition: misdirection allows no weight to verdict under s.307 like appeal

precedents.citation: Mushtak Hussein v. The State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: In Mushtak Hussein v. The State of Bombay, this Court laid down Unless therefore it is established in a case that there has been a serious misdirection by the judge in charging the jury which has occasioned a failure of justice and has misled the jury in giving its verdict, the verdict of the jury cannot be set aside.

precedents.case_name: Mushtak Hussein v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: misdirection must occasion failure of justice to vitiate verdict

precedents.citation: Smt. Nagindra Bala Mitra v. Sunil Chandra Roy

anchor.surface_text: This view has been restated by this Court in a recent decision, viz., Smt. Nagindra Bala Mitra v. Sunil Chandra Roy.

precedents.case_name: Nagindra Bala Mitra v Sunil Chandra Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: restates rule on misdirection occasioning failure of justice

precedents.citation: Woolmington v. The Director of Public Prosecutions

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, prefer not to refer to them, except to one of the leading decisions on the subject, namely, Woolmington v. The Director of Public Prosecutions.

precedents.case_name: Woolmington v Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents.cited_proposition: prosecution bears burden of guilt, accused raises doubt
precedents.cited_holding: golden thread: prosecution proves guilt, subject to exceptions

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed by learned counsel for the accused on the decision of the Privy Council in Attygalle v. Emperor in support of the contention that notwithstanding s. 105 of the Evidence Act, the burden of establishing the absence of accident within the meaning of s. 80 of the Indian Penal Code is on the prosecution.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.106-like provision does not shift burden to prove no crime

precedents.citation: The State of Madras v. Vaidyanatha Iyer 1

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this Court in The State of Madras v. Vaidyanatha Iyer 1 , which deals with s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, and C.S.D. Swami v. The State 2 , which considers the scope of s. 5 3  of the said Act,

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v Vaidyanatha Iyer
precedents.cited_proposition: statute can shift burden of ingredients of offence

anchor.surface_text: and C.S.D. Swami v. The State 2 , which considers the scope of s. 5 3  of the said Act, are examples of a statute throwing the burden of proving and even of establishing the absence of some of the ingredients of the offence on the accused

precedents.cited_proposition: burden on accused for absence of offence ingredients under statute

precedents.citation: Holmes v. Director of Public Prosecution 1

anchor.surface_text: The House of Lords in Holmes v. Director of Public Prosecution 1 laid down the law in England thus If there is no sufficient material, even on a view of the evidence most favourable to the accused, for a jury  which means a reasonable jury  to form the view that a reasonable person so provoked could be driven,

precedents.case_name: Holmes v Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents.cited_proposition: judge decides if evidence supports provocation for reasonable jury

anchor.surface_text: In this context reliance is placed upon two English decisions, namely, R. Roberts 1 and R. v. Attfield 2 . In the former case the appellant was prosecuted for the murder of a girl by shooting her with a service rifle and he pleaded accident as his defence.

precedents.cited_proposition: omission to refer evidence not misdirection if counsel commented

anchor.surface_text: R. Roberts 1 and R. v. Attfield 2 . In the former case ... In the latter case the facts were simple and the evidence was short the judge summed up the case directing the jury as to the law but did not deal with evidence except in regard to the appellants character.

precedents.cited_proposition: no need to review evidence in simple cases
